title: Column aliases are used mainly to shorten code and make column names more readable.

inline_content.Text: Column aliases are used mainly to shorten code and make column names more readable.

title: Code becomes shorter as long table names and unnecessary identification of columns
(e.g., there may be 2 IDs in the table, but only one is used in the statement)
i
can be avoided. Along with
table aliases
a
http://stackoverflow.com/documentation/sql/222/select/5237/selecting-with-table-alias#t=201608310647581262872
this allows you to use longer descriptive names in your database structure while keeping queries upon that structure concise.

inline_content.Text: Code becomes shorter as long table names and unnecessary identification of columns
(e.g., there may be 2 IDs in the table, but only one is used in the statement)
this allows you to use longer descriptive names in your database structure while keeping queries upon that structure concise.

title: Furthermore they are sometimes
required
i
, for instance in views, in order to name computed outputs.

inline_content.Text: , for instance in views, in order to name computed outputs.

title: Aliases can be created in all versions of SQL using double quotes (
c

inline_content.Text: Aliases can be created in all versions of SQL using double quotes (

title:
SELECT 
    FName AS "First Name", 
    MName AS "Middle Name",
    LName AS "Last Name"
FROM Employees

content_resolved.code:
SELECT 
    FName AS "First Name", 
    MName AS "Middle Name",
    LName AS "Last Name"
FROM Employees

title: You can use single quotes (
c
), double quotes (
c
) and square brackets (
c
) to create an alias in Microsoft SQL Server.

inline_content.Text: ) to create an alias in Microsoft SQL Server.

title:
SELECT 
    FName AS "First Name", 
    MName AS 'Middle Name',
    LName AS [Last Name]
FROM Employees

content_resolved.code:
SELECT 
    FName AS "First Name", 
    MName AS 'Middle Name',
    LName AS [Last Name]
FROM Employees

title: First Name | Middle Name | Last Name ––––– |––––– | ———–

inline_content.Text: First Name | Middle Name | Last Name ––––– |––––– | ———–

FName
c
and
LName
c
columns with a given name (an alias). This is achieved using the
AS
c
operator followed by the alias, or simply writing alias directly after the column name. This means that the following query has the same outcome as the above.

title:
SELECT 
    FName "First Name", 
    MName "Middle Name",
    LName "Last Name"

content_resolved.code:
SELECT 
    FName "First Name", 
    MName "Middle Name",
    LName "Last Name"

title: However, the explicit version (i.e., using the
AS
c

title: If the alias has a single word that is not a reserved word, we can write it without single quotes, double quotes or brackets:

inline_content.Text: If the alias has a single word that is not a reserved word, we can write it without single quotes, double quotes or brackets:

title:
SELECT 
    FName AS FirstName, 
    LName AS LastName
FROM Employees

content_resolved.code:
SELECT 
    FName AS FirstName, 
    LName AS LastName
FROM Employees

title: A further variation available in MS SQL Server amongst others is
<alias> = <column-or-calculation>
c
, for instance:

inline_content.Text: A further variation available in MS SQL Server amongst others is

title:
SELECT FullName = FirstName + ' ' + LastName, 
       Addr1    = FullStreetAddress,
       Addr2    = TownName
FROM CustomerDetails

content_resolved.code:
SELECT FullName = FirstName + ' ' + LastName, 
       Addr1    = FullStreetAddress,
       Addr2    = TownName
FROM CustomerDetails

title:
SELECT FirstName + ' ' + LastName As FullName
       FullStreetAddress          As Addr1,
       TownName                   As Addr2
FROM CustomerDetails

content_resolved.code:
SELECT FirstName + ' ' + LastName As FullName
       FullStreetAddress          As Addr1,
       TownName                   As Addr2
FROM CustomerDetails

title: Michael Williams | 999 High End Dr | Williamsburgh

inline_content.Text: Michael Williams | 999 High End Dr | Williamsburgh

title: Some find using
c
instead of
As
c
easier to read, though many recommend against this format, mainly because it is not standard so not widely supported by all databases. It may cause confusion with other uses of the
c
character.

inline_content.Text: easier to read, though many recommend against this format, mainly because it is not standard so not widely supported by all databases. It may cause confusion with other uses of the

title: Also, if you
need
i
to use reserved words, you can use brackets or quotes to escape:

inline_content.Text: to use reserved words, you can use brackets or quotes to escape:

title:
SELECT
    FName as "SELECT",
    MName as "FROM",
    LName as "WHERE"
FROM Employees

content_resolved.code:
SELECT
    FName as "SELECT",
    MName as "FROM",
    LName as "WHERE"
FROM Employees

title: Likewise, you can escape keywords in MSSQL with all different approaches:

inline_content.Text: Likewise, you can escape keywords in MSSQL with all different approaches:

title:
SELECT 
    FName AS "SELECT", 
    MName AS 'FROM',
    LName AS [WHERE]
FROM Employees

content_resolved.code:
SELECT 
    FName AS "SELECT", 
    MName AS 'FROM',
    LName AS [WHERE]
FROM Employees

title: Also, a column alias may be used any of the final clauses of the same query, such as an
ORDER BY
c

inline_content.Text: Also, a column alias may be used any of the final clauses of the same query, such as an

title:
SELECT 
    FName AS FirstName, 
    LName AS LastName
FROM 
    Employees 
ORDER BY 
    LastName DESC

content_resolved.code:
SELECT 
    FName AS FirstName, 
    LName AS LastName
FROM 
    Employees 
ORDER BY 
    LastName DESC

title:
SELECT
    FName AS SELECT,
    LName AS FROM
FROM 
    Employees
ORDER BY 
    LastName DESC

content_resolved.code:
SELECT
    FName AS SELECT,
    LName AS FROM
FROM 
    Employees
ORDER BY 
    LastName DESC
